citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care.
citations.narrative:
On January 9, 2024 a live rabbit (#1985) was discovered in a freezer used to store euthanized animals. The rabbit had
chewed out of the bag it was in and was moving around the freezer. It was then euthanized by the Attending Veterinarian.
The rabbit was one of 16 rabbits that has been euthanized the previous day and placed in the freezer. Prior to euthanasia,
the rabbits received an injection of a ketamine/xylazine combination to provide anesthesia and were then euthanized
together in a CO2 container. The facility Stand Operating Procedures (SOP) states that all animals must remain in the
euthanasia container until “all signs of breathing have ceased. This may take up to 20 minutes…” and can then be placed
in the freezer. The facility’s investigation into this event points out that technicians must “inspect each animal for breathing
prior to storing in the freezer. Since the animals are anesthetized prior to euthanasia, this can be difficult to see.”
The facilities investigation of the event also states that the technician performing the euthanasia did not allow the rabbits
enough exposure time to the CO2. The facility investigation says the technician only left the rabbits exposed to CO2 for
10 minutes. The AV says they are trained to leave them in for 20 minutes. The facility investigation also says that too
many rabbits were in the chamber. The SOP does not specify a maximum number, but the AV states they are trained to
only do a maximum of 8. The regulator that controls the flow of CO2 into the chamber had recently been replaced and
that may have cut the flow to the chamber by 50% according to the facility investigation and it was noted that the
technician only filled the chamber for 2 to 3 minutes, which may have inadequately filled the chamber. The SOP states
that the chamber “must be filled with a slow flow of gas until full” but doesn’t provide further guidance.
Failure to use appropriate euthanasia methods, including absolute confirmation of death, does not ensure that the
procedure meets the regulatory definition of euthanasia requiring that each animal’s death is rapid without evidence of
pain and distress.
Research facilities must establish and maintain programs of adequate veterinary care that provide clear guidance to
personnel involved in the care and use of animals regarding handling, immobilization, anesthesia, analgesia,
tranquilization, and euthanasia. The facility is in the process of revising euthanasia SOPs and improving training for the
employees who administer it.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the attending veterinarian.
n

narrative:
2.33(b)(4)  Critical
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care. 
On January 9, 2024 a live rabbit (#1985) was discovered in a freezer used to store euthanized animals. The rabbit had 
chewed out of the bag it was in and was moving around the freezer. It was then euthanized by the Attending Veterinarian. 
The rabbit was one of 16 rabbits that has been euthanized the previous day and placed in the freezer. Prior to euthanasia, 
the rabbits received an injection of a ketamine/xylazine combination to provide anesthesia and were then euthanized 
together in a CO2 container. The facility Stand Operating Procedures (SOP) states that all animals must remain in the 
euthanasia container until “all signs of breathing have ceased. This may take up to 20 minutes…” and can then be placed 
in the freezer. The facility’s investigation into this event points out that technicians must “inspect each animal for breathing 
prior to storing in the freezer. Since the animals are anesthetized prior to euthanasia, this can be difficult to see.”  
The facilities investigation of the event also states that the technician performing the euthanasia did not allow the rabbits 
enough exposure time to the CO2. The facility investigation says the technician only left the rabbits exposed to CO2 for 
10 minutes. The AV says they are trained to leave them in for 20 minutes. The facility investigation also says that too 
many rabbits were in the chamber. The SOP does not specify a maximum number, but the AV states they are trained to 
only do a maximum of 8. The regulator that controls the flow of CO2 into the chamber had recently been replaced and 
that may have cut the flow to the chamber by 50% according to the facility investigation and it was noted that the 
technician only filled the chamber for 2 to 3 minutes, which may have inadequately filled the chamber. The SOP states 
that the chamber “must be filled with a slow flow of gas until full” but doesn’t provide further guidance.  
Failure to use appropriate euthanasia methods, including absolute confirmation of death, does not ensure that the 
procedure meets the regulatory definition of euthanasia requiring that each animal’s death is rapid without evidence of 
pain and distress. 
Research facilities must establish and maintain programs of adequate veterinary care that provide clear guidance to 
personnel involved in the care and use of animals regarding handling, immobilization, anesthesia, analgesia, 
tranquilization, and euthanasia. The facility is in the process of revising euthanasia SOPs and improving training for the 
employees who administer it. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the attending veterinarian.

n
